Title: Evaluating Human-AI Collaboration: A Review and Methodological Framework
Authors: George Fragiadakis, Christos Diou, G. Kousiouris, Mara Nikolaidou
Abstract summary: The paper proposes a framework to evaluate human-AI collaboration, including in safety-critical or complex systems, by considering quantitative and qualitative metrics across different collaboration modes.

Title: Enhancing Counter Drone Operations Through Human-AI Collaboration: A Hierarchical Decision-Making Framework
Authors: Varun Mehta, Kesav Kaza, Fardad Dadboud, M. Bolic, I. Mantegh
Venue: Symposium on Dependable Autonomic and Secure Computing
Abstract summary: The paper proposes a human-AI collaboration framework for drone detection, tracking, and classification to address the limitations of supervised learning models.

Title: Human-AI Collaboration in Decision-Making: Beyond Learning to Defer
Authors: Diogo Leitão, Pedro Saleiro, Mário A. T. Figueiredo, P. Bizarro
Abstract summary: Existing evaluation frameworks for human-AI collaboration, such as learning to defer, have limitations in real-world settings like capacity management and dynamic environments.

Title: Evaluation framework to guide implementation of AI systems into healthcare settings
Authors: S. Reddy, Wendy Rogers, Ville-Petteri Makinen, E. Coiera, Pieta Brown, M. Wenzel, Eva Weicken, Sabahat J. Ansari, P. Mathur, A. Casey, Blair Kelly
Abstract summary: The paper presents a framework called TEHAI to evaluate the translational aspects of AI systems in healthcare, including capability, utility and adoption.

Title: Designing human-AI systems for complex settings: ideas from distributed, joint, and self-organising perspectives of sociotechnical systems and cognitive work analysis
Authors: N. Naikar, Ashleigh Brady, Glennn Moy, H. Kwok
Abstract summary: Existing evaluation frameworks for human-AI collaboration are limited by their dyadic nature, and contemporary perspectives of sociotechnical systems like distributed cognition and self-organization can inform new design frameworks.

Title: Sociotechnical Safety Evaluation of Generative AI Systems
Authors: Laura Weidinger, Maribeth Rauh, Nahema Marchal, Arianna Manzini, Lisa Anne Hendricks, Juan Mateos-Garcia, Stevie Bergman, Jackie Kay, Conor Griffin, Ben Bariach, Iason Gabriel, Verena Rieser, William S. Isaac
Abstract summary: The paper proposes a three-layered sociotechnical framework for evaluating the safety of generative AI systems, going beyond just capability evaluations.

Title: A systematic review of human-AI interaction in autonomous ship systems
Abstract summary: The paper reviews human-AI interaction in autonomous ship systems, but does not address limitations of existing evaluation frameworks for human-AI collaboration in safety-critical or complex systems like DER operations.

Title: Extending a Human-AI Collaboration Framework with Dynamism and Sociality
Authors: Michael J. Muller, Justin D. Weisz
Venue: Symposium on Human-Computer Interaction for Work
Abstract summary: The paper proposes an integrated framework for analyzing dynamic and social aspects of human-AI collaboration in complex organizational applications.
